questions.text: Identify the breast condition from the image shown below
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mondor's disease Mondor's disease is evident in the lateral aspect of the right breast in the image. Mondor’s disease: Mondor’s disease is thrombophlebitis of the superficial veins of the breast and anterior chest wall, although it may also occur in the arm. In the absence of injury or infection, the cause of thrombophlebitis (like that of spontaneous thrombophlebitis in other sites) is obscure. The pathognomonic feature is a thrombosed subcutaneous cord, usually attached to the skin. When the skin over the breast is stretched by raising the arm, a narrow, shallow, subcutaneous groove alongside the cord becomes apparent. The differential diagnosis is lymphatic permeation from an occult carcinoma of the breast. The only treatment required is to restrict arm movements. The condition usually subsides within a few months without recurrence, complications, or deformity. There are case reports of Mondor’s disease being associated with the subsequent development of malignancy, although coincidental malignancy is more likely.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option A : Breast cysts are common in the 35- to 55-year-old age group and usually present as a painless lump Cysts are often multiple, may be bilateral, and can mimic malignancy Option B : An abscess presents as a fluctuant lump (in a deep-seated abscess fluctuation may be absent) with pain, signs of inflammation, fever, malaise, and difficulty in feeding. It may also be associated with enlarged tender axillary nodes Option C : Galactocele is rare and usually presents as a solitary subareolar milk-filled cyst seen during or just after lactation.

questions.text: Three days after delivery of a male new-born by lower segment transverse cesarean section, a 36-year-old gravida 1, para 1 woman has fever and pain in her left leg. The patient has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 5 years and continued to smoke during her pregnancy. Her temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), her pulse is 110/min, and her blood pressure is 110/80 mm Hg. Examination shows an oedematous, erythematous, and warm left leg. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. The uterus is non-tender and palpated at the umbilicus. Ultrasonography of the left leg shows an incompressible left popliteal vein. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Low Molecular Weight Heparin This patient presents with fever, leg pain, warmth, edema, and erythema, 3 days after delivery, which suggests a diagnosis of postpartum deep venous thrombosis (DVT) . Compression ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis. Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state; the risk of venous thromboembolisms reaches its peak in the first 6 weeks postpartum when hypercoagulability is accompanied by endothelial injury (e.g., due to surgical delivery) and possibly venous stasis (due to immobilization after delivery). Smoking also increases the risk of DVT , as does delivery via cesarean section, maternal age > 35 years, and preterm delivery. LMWH, administered subcutaneously, is the initial treatment of choice because of its immediate antithrombotic effect and safety during breastfeeding . If no significant bleeding has occurred, it can safely be started 12 hours after the caesarean section.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Embolectomy is not indicated in the treatment of deep venous thrombosis (DVT) but may be considered for patients with acute limb ischemia (ALI) within the first 6–24 hours to restore arterial blood supply in a viable, nonthreatened limb. Although ALI can manifest with acute pain, it is unlikely to cause significant swelling and redness Instead, patients with ALI typically have a source of arterial embolus (e.g., atrial fibrillation, myocardial infarction) and present with a cool limb, decreased peripheral pulses, and possibly sensory symptoms. Also, Compression Ultrasonography confirms DVT. Option: C. Surgical fasciotomy is the treatment of choice to relieve the pressure, and thus, restore perfusion in patients with compartment syndrome. Acute compartment syndrome is a possible cause of postpartum limb pain, as it can be triggered by intrapartum hypotension (e.g., due to blood loss) or after the application of vasoconstrictive therapeutic agents (e.g., oxytocin to induce labor). In early stages, it can present with swelling, paraesthesia, and pain that is exacerbated by passive stretching or extension of the muscles; distal pulses are often initially palpable and do not rule out the diagnosis. However, physical examination typically shows very tight, “wood-like” muscles. This patient's examination findings suggest deep venous thrombosis rather than compartment syndrome. Option: D. Warfarin (a vitamin K antagonist) is commonly prescribed for oral anticoagulation in patients with deep venous thrombosis (DVT); however, it is not indicated as initial monotherapy in patients with acute DVT. Warfarin monotherapy induces a transient hypercoagulable state in the first few days of therapy as it decreases anticoagulant proteins C and S because of their shorter half-life (6–10h) before reducing the coagulant factors II, VII, IX, and X (half-life of 2–4 days). To not worsen the patient's DVT and/or cause warfarin-induced skin necrosis, the initial therapy must contain another drug that has an immediate antithrombotic effect, before introducing oral anticoagulation.

Extraedge:

The most common presentation of a DVT is pain and swelling, especially in the calf, usually in one leg; however, bilateral DVTs are common, occurring in up to 30%. The diagnosis of DVT and pulmonary embolism should be established by special investigations as the symptoms and signs are non-specific and may be absent.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of severe dyspnoea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain for 20 minutes. Three weeks ago, she underwent surgery for a total right knee replacement. The patient appears distressed. Her pulse is 112/min, respirations are 24/min, and her blood pressure is 88/55 mm Hg. Examination shows jugular venous distention. There is a mildly tender surgical scar on her right knee. A CT scan of the chest is shown. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Alteplase This patient's CT scan shows evidence of a large pulmonary embolism (PE). In cases of massive PE with hemodynamic instability (e.g., SBP < 90 mm Hg), thrombolysis with alteplase or other recombinant tissue plasminogen activators (tPA) is indicated. Because of the associated significant risk of bleeding, there are several relative and absolute contraindications to thrombolysis. Surgery within the past 10 days is a relative contraindication, but this patient underwent surgery 3 weeks ago. Therefore, alteplase would be the most appropriate treatment. Anticoagulation with heparin, Rivaroxaban, warfarin, or apixaban is also an appropriate treatment for patients with PE. However, these agents are typically used in patients who remain hemodynamically stable.

Highyeild:

Pulmonary Embolism PE is not usually an immediate complication but can present in the early postoperative period. Thrombus can arise from DVT in the legs/pelvis, venae cavae, or the right atrium. Signs and symptoms depend on the size of the embolus and may range from dyspnoea, cough, and pleuritic chest pain to sudden cardiovascular collapse Diagnosis : Two-level pulmonary embolism (PE) Wells score. Clinical features Points Clinical signs and symptoms of DVT (minimum of leg swelling and pain with palpation of the deep veins) 3 An alternative diagnosis is less likely than PE 3 Heart rate more than 100 beats per minute 1.5 Immobilisation for more than 3 days or surgery in the previous 4 weeks 1.5 Previous DVT/PE 1.5 Haemoptysis 1 Malignancy (on treatment, treated in the last 6 months or palliative 1 Clinical probability simplified score Points PE likely More than 4 points PE unlikely 4 points or less Treatment : Thrombolysis and Initial resuscitation with oxygen therapy and analgesia Parenteral Anticoagulation followed by long-term anticoagulation

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Endovascular stent-grafting can be used in the treatment of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. Patients typically present with severe, tearing chest pain, hypertension, and asymmetric pulses. Hypotension, severe dyspnoea, and cough, as seen in this patient, are less common manifestations of type A (proximal) aortic dissection. The patient's CT scan also shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than a tear in the aortic intima, which would be typical in a case of dissection. Option: B. Tube thoracostomy is used in the treatment of tension pneumothorax, which can manifest with dyspnoea, pleuritic chest pain, cough, JVD, and hypotension, which are seen in this patient. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism rather than air in the pleural space with tracheal deviation, which is typical in cases of tension pneumothorax. Option: D. Coronary angioplasty is used in the treatment of myocardial infarction. Myocardial infarction can manifest with chest pain, JVD, and hypotension, which are seen in this patient. However, her CT scan shows a vascular filling defect consistent with a pulmonary embolism.

Extraedge:

Some patients have no symptoms of thrombosis and may first present with signs of a pulmonary embolus, e.g. pleuritic chest pain, hemoptysis, and shortness of breath. Clinical signs and symptoms of pulmonary embolus occur in about 10% of patients with confirmed DVT. Low-grade pyrexia may be present, especially in a patient who is having repeated pulmonary embolus.

questions.text: A 49-year-old man comes to the physician because of tender, red nodules that appeared on his chest 3 days ago. Three weeks ago, he had similar symptoms in his right lower limb and another episode in his left foot; both episodes resolved spontaneously. He also has diarrhea and has had a poor appetite for 1 month. He has a history of dry cough and joint pain, for which he takes albuterol and aspirin as needed. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 15 years. He does not drink alcohol. Physical examination shows a linear, erythematous lesion on the right anterior chest wall, through which a cord-like structure can be palpated. The lungs are clear to auscultation. The abdomen is soft, nontender, and non-distended. Examination of the legs is normal. An ultrasound of the legs shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the diagnosis of the underlying condition?
questions.correct_answer: C. CT scan of the abdomen
questions.explanation:
Solution:

CT scan of the abdomen A cord-like structure underneath a tender, erythematous lesion that changes location is consistent with migratory, superficial thrombophlebitis as a result of a hypercoagulable state. Recurrent migratory thrombophlebitis may be secondary to an occult malignancy, classically pancreatic cancer. This phenomenon, known as Trousseau syndrome , can occur months to years before a malignant process is detected. This patient has additional symptoms that suggest pancreatic cancer, including diarrhea (possibly steatorrhea secondary to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency) and poor appetite, and has a long smoking history, which is a risk factor. Abdominal CT is the most specific and sensitive diagnostic test for detecting underlying visceral cancer.

Highyeild:

Superficial Thrombophlebitis Causes : External Trauma Venipunctures Infusion of Hyperosmolar Solutions and Drugs Presence of an Intravenous cannula for a longer time Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger’s disease) and malignancy, especially of the pancreas, can lead to fitting thrombophlebitis (thrombophlebitis migrans) Polycythaemia, thrombocytosis, and sickle cell disease Presentation: Vein feels solid and tender on palpation Investigations: Full blood count, coagulation screen and duplex scan of the deep veins, Endoscopy and Imaging (If Associated malignancy) Treatment : NSAIDs Topical Heparinoid Ligation Anticoagulation (associated DVT or Thrombophilia)

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. An abnormally reduced ankle-brachial index would be consistent with thromboangiitis obliterans (TAO), also known as Buerger’s disease. While this patient has migratory superficial thrombophlebitis and a history of smoking, he does not have a history of the Raynaud phenomenon or intermittent claudication. Furthermore, there are no abnormalities in his extremity pulses, physical exam, or ultrasound that would suggest TAO. Option: B. While abnormal findings on coagulation studies may provide further support for this patient's hypercoagulable state, they would not provide any additional diagnostic information beyond what has been detected clinically nor elucidate the underlying cause of this patient's hypercoagulable state. Option: D. The presence of antiphospholipid antibodies would be consistent with a diagnosis of antiphospholipid syndrome (APS), possibly secondary to systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). While APS causes a hypercoagulable state, resulting in arterial and venous thrombi, the transient and migratory quality of this patient's symptoms suggests a different dermatologic process. Furthermore, this patient has no features suspicious of SLE.

Extraedge:

The presence of an intravenous cannula for longer than 24–48 hours often leads to local thrombosis. Most patients are treated with NSAIDs and topical heparinoid preparations and the condition resolves spontaneously.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman with hypertension comes to the physician because of swelling and pain in both legs for the past year. The symptoms are worse at night and improve in the morning. Current medications include losartan and metoprolol. Her temperature is 36°C (96.8°F), her pulse is 67/min, and her blood pressure is 142/88 mm Hg. Examination shows normal heart sounds; there is no jugular venous distention. Her abdomen is soft and the liver edge is not palpable. Examination of the lower extremities shows bilateral pitting edema and prominent superficial veins. The skin is warm and there is reddish-brown discoloration on both ankles. Laboratory studies show normal serum creatinine and normal urinalysis. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increased Venous Valve Reflux A female patient of advanced age with bilateral leg swelling, skin discoloration, and pain most likely has venous hypertension due to chronic venous insufficiency (CVI) and varicose veins. In CVI, defective venous valve leaflets result in the reflux of venous blood back into the periphery, leading to increased venous pressure (hydrostatic pressure) and subsequent extravasation of venous blood into the interstitium. Plasma proteins in the interstitium in turn cause edema and tissue hypoperfusion, which results in inflammation, atrophy, and possibly ulcer formation.

Highyeild:

Chronic venous insufficiency : Signs: Varicose veins, pigmentation, lipodermatosclerosis, and venous ulceration Types: Primary: Primary CVI results from intrinsic abnormalities of the vein wall Secondary: Secondary valvular reflux is diagnosed when an identifiable cause is present. The most frequent secondary cause is DVT Diagnosis: Plethysmography (Non-Invasive) Venous Duplex Ultrasound (Gold Standard) Treatment : Non-Operative: Compression Therapy and Skin Substitutes Operative : Insufficiency Perforator Vein Ligation Superficial Venous Surgery Deep/Venous Valvular Reconstruction Venous Stenting

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Decreased lymphatic flow can result in lymphedema, a type of nonpitting edema that results due to the accumulation of filtered lymph fluid in the interstitium. This patient's pitting edema, chronic skin changes, and lack of risk factors for lymphedema (radiation therapy, surgery, tumor obstruction) suggest a different underlying mechanism. Option: B. Decreased arteriolar resistance can be caused by medications that induce vascular smooth muscle relaxation, such as dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (e.g., amlodipine). Patients on dihydropyridines can also present with pitting edema. However, this patient is not taking dihydropyridines, and neither losartan nor metoprolol cause decreased arteriolar resistance. Option: D. Increased capillary permeability is seen in patients with systemic inflammation and/or distributive shock (e.g., from anaphylaxis or sepsis). Extravasation of plasma proteins through the permeable capillary walls causes edema. This patient is afebrile, not tachycardic or hypotensive, and has no symptoms to suggest infection or inflammation. Her chronic skin changes suggest a different underlying cause of her symptoms.

Extraedge:

Horse chestnut seed extract has been shown to be a safe and efficacious treatment for chronic venous hypertension, improving symptoms and reducing leg volume. A number of biological dressings have been developed, including fetal keratinocytes and collagen meshes, which have been shown to improve healing; however, they are not cost-effective for the majority of ulcers.

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of dull, persistent pain and swelling in her right leg. The pain is worse at the end of the day and is relieved by walking or elevating her feet. Two years ago, she developed acute deep vein thrombosis in her right calf after a long flight, which was treated with anticoagulants for 6 months. Physical examination shows 2+ pitting edema of her right leg. The skin around the right ankle shows a reddish-brown discoloration and multiple telangiectasias. She has dilated veins in the right leg. Which of the following is most likely to establish the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Duplex Ultrasonography The patient’s unilateral chronic dull pain, edema, dilated veins in the lower extremity, and history of DVT suggest Varicose veins due to venous hypertension.

Highyeild:

Duplex ultrasonography (compression ultrasonography) is the first-line investigation in patients with features suggestive of varicose veins Evidence of venous reflux on duplex ultrasonography confirms the diagnosis of Varicose veins and venous hypertension. Duplex ultrasonography can help determine the course of treatment by identifying which valves are incompetent and assessing the patency of the previously thrombosed deep veins.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Computed tomography scan with contrast of the lower extremities is used to evaluate patients for deep infections (e.g., abscesses), malignancy, or injury in the lower extremities. It is not used to evaluate varicose veins and venous hypertension. Option: B. The D-dimer assay is a nonspecific test that is indicated for patients with a low pretest probability of acute deep venous thrombosis (DVT) to rule out an acute thrombotic event. The test has a high negative predictive value (> 95%); therefore, a negative test result effectively rules out the presence of a deep venous thrombosis or a pulmonary embolism. Option: C- The ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) is used to screen for peripheral arterial disease (PAD) in patients who present with lower limb pain that suggests claudication pain (i.e., pain on walking that is relieved with rest). This patient's pain improves with walking, making PAD an unlikely cause of her symptoms. Her symptoms are consistent with a pathology of the venous system, which cannot be evaluated with ABPI.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 4, para 3, comes to the physician because of left ankle swelling for 2 months. She notes that the swelling is present throughout the day and decreases when she goes to sleep. One year ago, she has had an episode of deep venous thrombosis after the delivery of her third child. Her pre-pregnancy BMI was 34 kg/m2. Examination shows distended, tortuous veins in the legs bilaterally and pitting edema of the left ankle. There are erythematous scaling patches on the medial side of the left ankle. Duplex ultrasonography is performed. Which of the following directions of blood flow would most likely confirm the diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Anterior tibial vein to popliteal vein

options.label: B
options.text: Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein

options.label: C
options.text: Femoral Vein to external iliac vein

options.label: D
options.text: Great saphenous vein to femoral vein

questions.correct_answer: B. Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Popliteal vein to small saphenous vein Distended and tortuous veins in both legs, ankle edema, and skin changes on the medial ankle indicate venous hypertension and varicose veins. Venous blood flowing from the deep popliteal vein to the superficial small saphenous vein indicates retrograde blood flow and confirms the diagnosis of venous hypertension.

Highyeild:

Normally, the small saphenous vein would arise from the dorsal venous arch and drain into the popliteal vein at the sapheno-popliteal junction. In a patient with chronic venous disease, however, incompetence of the venous valves caused by elevated venous pressure (e.g., due to pregnancy, increased BMI, prior thrombosis) leads to blood reflux from deep into superficial veins. This results in the formation of varicose veins, and ultimately edema and skin changes (e.g., stasis dermatitis) First-line treatment consists of conservative measures such as leg elevation, compression therapy, and the application of topical dermatologic agents.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Venous blood flowing from the anterior tibial vein to the popliteal vein indicates normal blood flow from a peripheral deep vein to a deep vein. Venous hypertension, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins. Option: C. Venous blood flowing from the femoral vein to the external iliac vein indicates normal blood flow from a deep vein to a proximal deep vein. Venous hypertension, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins Option: D. Venous blood flowing from the great saphenous vein to the femoral vein indicates normal blood flow from a superficial to a deep vein. Venous hypertension, however, is characterized by retrograde blood flow, or venous reflux from the deep veins into the superficial veins. (a) Anatomy of the deep veins of the lower limb; (b) Anatomy of the superficial veins of the lower limb (great saphenous axis); (c) Anatomy of the superficial veins of the lower limb (small saphenous axis).

Extraedge:

Up to 40% of the adult population in resource-rich countries have diseases of the veins of the leg. As the sole of the foot is often placed under significant pressure, the majority of the venous drainage of the foot is into the dorsal venous arch, running in the subcutaneous tissues over the metatarsal heads.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of a rash on her ankles with intermittent itching. After the rash developed, she started applying a new scented lotion to her legs daily. She works as a cashier at a grocery store. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. Current medications include metformin and enalapril. Examination shows enlarged superficial veins of the right lower extremity and red-brown discoloration with indistinct margins over the medial ankles. There is 1+ edema in the lower extremities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s skin findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Contact of Antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dermal deposition of hemosiderin This woman has a pruritic, red-brown rash over medial ankles, varicose veins, and bilateral lower extremity edema. Her occupation likely requires her to stand for prolonged periods. These findings suggest stasis dermatitis due to venous hypertension.

Highyeild:

Dermal deposition of hemosiderin is a key feature of stasis dermatitis. Elevated venous pressures from chronic venous disease result in red blood cell breakdown, which leads to hemosiderin production. Hemosiderin penetrates defective capillaries and accumulates in the dermis, which causes a pruritic, red-brown rash, as seen in this patent. The medial ankles are the most frequently involved site.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Contact of antigen with pre-sensitized T lymphocytes is the underlying mechanism of allergic contact dermatitis, which usually manifests with a pruritic, erythematous rash with indistinct margins. Products that contain fragrance are common contact allergens. However, this patient's rash preceded her use of a new lotion. Additionally, allergic contact dermatitis typically only causes edema in areas that have thin skin (e.g., the lips and eyelids) and does not result in varicose veins. Option: B. Insufficient arterial tissue perfusion can cause ischemic ulcers, which often manifest at sites of focal pressure such as the medial malleoli. These ulcers develop in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD), which is associated with advanced age, diabetes, and hypertension. However, they are typically painful and well-demarcated. Additionally, this patient does not have other common symptoms of PAD such as claudication, hair loss on the leg, or nail changes. Option: C. Tinea pedis, a dermatophyte infection, most commonly develops on the feet and causes a pruritic, scaly rash. Erythema can also occur but is less common. Tinea pedis typically affects the digital interspaces and soles of the feet (not the medial ankles) and is not associated with edema or varicose veins.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 1, para 0 at 11 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of left lower extremity pain and swelling. Her temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F). Physical examination shows a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. The overlying skin is erythematous and indurated. Duplex ultrasound shows vascular wall thickening and subcutaneous edema. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Superficial thrombophlebitis Superficial thrombophlebitis is usually a benign inflammation of veins and overlying tissue due to thrombosis. The inflamed veins, impacted with thrombotic material, manifest as palpable, nodular cords that remain visible when the limb is raised. There is a greater risk of thrombosis during pregnancy due to a combination of hypercoagulability (increased circulating clotting factors and RBCs) and elevated venous stasis (compression of the enlarged uterus on pelvic veins).

Highyeild:

Cardinal Signs: Rubor, Calor, Dolor, and Tumor describing a linear, erythematous, tender, and swollen lesion along the course of a superficial vein Predisposing risk factors : Recent surgery, recent childbirth, venous stasis, varicose veins, or IV drug use Diagnosis : Physical examination of an erythematous palpable cord coursing along a superficial vein, usually located along the lower extremities Duplex USG(Confirmatory) Treatment : Conservative Therapy: Anti-inflammatory Medication and Compression Stockings The recommended treatment of superficial thrombophlebitis, involving a ≥5 cm great saphenous vein segment is a mid treatment dose of LMWH (enoxaparin 60 mg daily subcutaneously) or fondaparinux (2.5 mg daily subcutaneously) for a 6-week period. A similar treatment is recommended if thrombophlebitis ascends the great saphenous vein within 3 cm from the saphenofemoral junction.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. DVT manifests with diffuse swelling, tenderness, and redness of the affected extremity. There is a higher risk of DVT during pregnancy because of an increase in coagulability and venous stasis. However, DVT would not show signs of inflammation (a tender, palpable cord with local erythema and induration or elevated temperature), and duplex ultrasound would not show vascular wall thickening or subcutaneous edema. Option: B. Varicose veins are common during pregnancy because the growing uterus places increased pressure on pelvic veins. However, they manifest as dark purple or blue, twisted, bulging, soft, non-tender cords, and usually show no signs of inflammation. Additionally, duplex ultrasound might show subcutaneous edema but not vascular wall thickening. Option: C. Lymphedema is a type of nonpitting edema caused by insufficient lymphatic drainage that occurs more commonly during pregnancy (pregnancy hormones induce changes in vascular permeability, promoting extravasation of fluids). Lymphedema is typically diffusely localized over the toes and feet; it would not manifest as a tender, palpable cord on the lateral aspect of the left lower leg. Additionally, duplex ultrasound would show subcutaneous edema but not vascular wall thickening.

Extraedge:

The presence of an intravenous cannula for longer than 24–48 hours often leads to local thrombosis. Most patients are treated with NSAIDs and topical heparinoid preparations and the condition resolves spontaneously.

questions.text: Three days after undergoing a laparoscopic colectomy, a 67-year-old man reports swelling and pain in his right leg. He was diagnosed with colon cancer 1 month ago. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F). Physical examination shows swelling of the right leg from the ankle to the thigh. There is no erythema or rash. Which of the following is likely to be most helpful in establishing the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Compression ultrasonography Compression ultrasonography is the test of choice for diagnosing DVT. It is affordable, reliable, and safe, making it an ideal first-line test. Sonographic findings that suggest a thrombus include a noncompressible vein, visible hyperechoic mass, and/or absent or abnormal venous flow.

Highyeild:

Deep Venous Thromboembolism : Formation of a semisolid coagulum within the venous system may occur in the superficial system (superficial vein thrombosis [SVT] or ‘thrombophlebitis’) or the deep system (deep vein thrombosis [DVT]). Etiology: contact of blood with an abnormal surface (e.g. endothelial damage) abnormal flow (e.g. stasis) abnormal blood (e.g. thrombophilia). Risk factors for venous thromboembolism. Patient factors • Age • Obesity • Varicose veins • Immobility • Pregnancy • Puerperium • High-dose oestrogen therapy • Previous deep vein thrombosis or pulmonary embolism • Thrombophilia (see Table 62.3) Disease or surgical procedure • Trauma or surgery, especially of pelvis, hip and lower limb • Malignancy, especially pelvic, and abdominal metastatic • Heart failure • Recent myocardial infarction • Paralysis of lower limb(s) • Infection • Inflammatory bowel disease • Nephrotic syndrome • Polycythaemia • Paraproteinaemia • Paroxysmal nocturnal haemoglobinuria antibody or lupus anticoagulant • Behçet's disease • Homocystinaemia Associated Conditions : Abnormalities of thrombosis and fibrinolysis (thrombophilia) that lead to an increased risk of venous thrombosis. Congenital • Deficiency of antithrombin III, protein C or protein S • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant • Factor V Leiden gene defect or activated protein C resistance • Dysfibrinogenaemias Acquired • Antiphospholipid antibody or lupus anticoagulant Presentation : Pain and Swelling (especially in the calf) Pleuritic Chest pain, Haemoptysis, and Shortness of Breath (Pulmonary Embolus) Cellulitic and Occasionally white or cyanosed (Phlemasia alba dolens and Phlegmasia cerulea dolens) Venous Gangrene (Neoplasm) Mild Pitting Oedema of the ankle, dilated surface veins, a stiff calf, and tenderness over the course of the deep veins Homan’s Sign - resistance (not pain) of the calf muscles to forcible dorsiflexion – is not specific and should not be elicited Signs of Cyanosis, dyspnea, raised neck veins a fixed split-second heart sound, and a pleural rub (Pulmonary Emboli) Investigations : Venous Duplex Ultrasound Compression Ultrasound Ascending Venography or MR Venography CT (Pulmonary angiogram) Modified Wells criteria for predicting deep vein thrombosis (DVT). Variable Score Lower limb trauma or surgery or immobilisation in a plaster cast 1 Bedridden for >3 days or surgery in last 4 weeks 1 Tenderness along the line of femoral or popliteal veins 1 Entire limb swollen 1 Calf >3 cm larger circumference than other side 10 cm below tibial tuberosity 1 Pitting oedema 1 Dilated collateral superficial veins (not varicose veins) 1 Previous DVT 1 Malignancy (including treatment up to 6 months ago) 1 Intravenous drug abuse 3 Alternative diagnosis more likely than DVT -2 Low probability (5%) of DVT (score -2 to 0); moderate probability (17%) of DVT (score 1 or 2); high probability (17-53%) of DVT (score >2). Treatment : Low Molecular Weigh Heparin Fondaparinux or Bivalirudin (Heparin Induced Thrombocytopenia) Inferior Vena cava filter Endovascular Surgery

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. D-dimer level testing is frequently used to rule out DVT. However, it should only be used when the pre-test probability is low (i.e., Wells score ≤ 1) rather than high, which is seen here. In addition, D-dimer testing is not recommended in postoperative patients because the concentration of D-dimer is rarely normal in this state (leading to frequent false positives) Option: B. CT pulmonary angiography is the test of choice for the diagnosis of pulmonary embolism (PE), for which the pre-test possibility can also be calculated using the Wells score. However, PE typically presents with chest pain, shortness of breath, and/or tachycardia, none of which this patient has. A CT pulmonary angiography would not be helpful in diagnosing this patient's likely DVT. Option: C. Blood cultures are useful in diagnosing bacteremia, which can be caused by cellulitis. Cellulitis typically manifests with fever as well as local swelling and pain. However, it also manifests with erythema, which is not seen in this patient. Moreover, cellulitis does not have a high Wells score.

Extraedge:

The most common presentation of a DVT is pain and swelling, especially in the calf, usually in one leg; however, bilateral DVTs are common, occurring in up to 30%. The diagnosis of DVT and pulmonary embolism should be established by special investigations as the symptoms and signs are non-specific and may be absent.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of pain and swelling in his left leg. He has a history of pancreatic cancer and is currently receiving chemotherapy. Three weeks ago, he had a similar episode in his right arm that resolved without treatment. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F). Palpation of the left leg shows a tender, cord-shaped structure medial to the medial condyle of the femur. The overlying skin is erythematous. Which of the following vessels is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Great saphenous vein The great saphenous vein (GSV) originates at the base of the hallux, continues proximally by passing anterior to the medial malleolus, and then courses along the posterior aspect of the medial femoral condyle before running deep into the thigh to join the femoral vein. The GSV and the small saphenous vein make up the main veins of the superficial venous system of the leg, which is commonly involved in cases of malignant migratory thrombophlebitis. Migratory thrombophlebitis in pancreatic cancer is believed to be a direct result of procoagulants by the tumor itself . This patient will require acute treatment with intravenous heparin followed by outpatient anticoagulation.

Highyeild:

This is the longest vein in the body and is the most frequently affected by superficial incompetence. The GSV passes anterior to the medial malleolus and ascends the leg accompanied by the saphenous nerve in the superficial tissues medial to the tibia, looping posteriorly at the level of the medial condyle of the femur and continuing in the medial thigh. In the groin, it unites with tributaries corresponding to the arterial branches of the common femoral artery, before piercing the cribriform fascia covering the saphenous opening (approximately 2.5 cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle, but often somewhat higher) and terminates by draining into the common femoral vein (CFV) at the saphenofemoral junction (SFJ)

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The posterior tibial vein is a deep vein that courses through the deep posterior compartment of the leg. This vein is susceptible to clotting but classically presents with calf pain, especially on ankle dorsiflexion (Homan's sign). It would not be appreciated medial to the medial femoral condyles. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins. Option: B. The anterior tibial vein is a deep vein that runs parallel to the anterior tibial artery in the anterior compartment of the leg. In cases of thrombophlebitis, skin changes, and pain are present along the anterior aspect of the leg but the vein can be difficult to palpate due to the overlying muscle bellies and the curved surface of the underlying tibia. In addition, malignant migratory thrombophlebitis generally affects superficial veins. Option: D. The popliteal vein gives rise to the femoral vein as it passes through the popliteal fossa. This vessel is commonly affected in migratory thrombophlebitis and would present as a palpable cord. However, it is appreciated in the popliteal fossa between the tendons of the hamstring muscles.

As the sole of the foot is often placed under significant pressure, the majority of the venous drainage of the foot is into the dorsal venous arch, running in the subcutaneous tissues over the metatarsal heads.

He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease and was started on hemodialysis 2 years ago. Prior to admission, his medications were insulin, enalapril, atorvastatin, and sevelamer. His temperature is 38.3°C (101°F), his pulse is 110/min, and his blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Examination shows a swollen, warm, and erythematous right calf. Dorsiflexion of the right foot causes severe pain in the right calf. The peripheral pulses are palpated bilaterally. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show. questions.text: A 38-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 32 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of a 1-day history of dyspnoea and left-sided chest pain that is worse when she breathes deeply. One week ago, she returned from a trip to Mumbai, where she had a 3-day episode of flu-like symptoms that resolved without treatment. The pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), her pulse is 118/min, her respirations are 28/min and slightly labored, and her blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 91%. Examination shows jugular venous distention and bilateral pitting edema below the knees that is worse on the left-side. There are decreased breath sounds over the left lung base. The uterus is consistent in size with a 32-week gestation. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased left ventricular ejection fraction on echocardiography

options.label: B
options.text: Depression of PR segment on ECG

options.label: C
options.text: Consolidation of left lung base on chest X-ray

questions.correct_answer: D. Noncompressible femoral vein on ultrasonography
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is the most common cause of pulmonary embolism. DVT of the left femoral vein would also explain this patient's more pronounced edema in the left leg. Both pregnancy and recent air travel are risk factors that likely contributed to this patient's development of DVT.

Pulmonary thromboembolism may result in a decrease in cardiac output but the LVEF is usually normal because LV systolic function and LV contractility remain unaffected. Instead, a dilated right ventricle with a decreased right ventricular ejection fraction would be more typical for patients with severe pulmonary embolism. Option: B. Depression of the PR segment on ECG is seen in acute viral pericarditis and atrial myocardial infarction. Acute pericarditis can result in tachycardia, dyspnoea, and chest pain that worsens with inspiration. However, other features such as fever and a pericardial friction rub would be present. This patient's aPTT remains normal despite heparin administration because heparin requires the presence of AT III to achieve its effect. questions.text: A 63-year-old woman comes to the OPD due to leg swelling that is especially bothersome in the evening. Her symptoms have gradually worsened over the last year. Her medical problems include hypertension treated with lisinopril and obstructive sleep apnoea for which she uses continuous positive airway pressure during sleep. She was hospitalized 2 years ago for a chest infection that was treated with antibiotics. The patient has smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years and does not drink alcohol. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg and pulse is 80/min. BMI is 32 kg/m². Jugular venous pulsation is seen 2 cm above the sternal angle with the head of the bed elevated to 45°. Chest examination shows bilateral scattered wheezes and prolonged expirations Her abdomen is soft and nondistended. She has bilateral 2+ pitting edema in her lower extremities to the MID shin with dilated and tortuous superficial veins. A small ulcer is noted on the left medial ankle. All peripheral pulses are palpable. Which of the following is most likely to relieve this patient's current symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Frequent leg elevation This patient's lower extremity swelling is likely due to chronic venous insufficiency (CVI), which is most commonly caused by incompetence of venous valves leading to venous hypertension in the deep venous system of the legs. Patients may present with leg discomfort, pain, or swelling that is typically worse in the evening or following prolonged standing and improves after walking or leg elevation. Pitting edema is the most common physical examination finding.

The most frequent secondary cause is DVT Diagnosis : Plethysmography (Non-Invasive) Venous Duplex Ultrasound (Gold Standard) Treatment : Non-Operative: Leg Elevation, Compression Therapy, and Skin Substitutes Operative : Insufficiency Perforator Vein Ligation Superficial Venous Surgery Deep/Venous Valvular Reconstruction Venous Stenting

Diuretics (furosemide) are useful in the management of heart failure, which is unlikely in this patient given the lack of dyspnoea and normal jugular venous pressure. Extensive DVT of the major axial deep venous channels of the lower extremity potentially complicated by venous gangrene and/or the need or amputation. questions.correct_answer: D. Perforating veins (perforators) joining the superficial and deep veins of the calf are valveless.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Perforating veins (perforators) joining the superficial and deep veins of the calf are valveless. In the calf and thigh, there are several perforating veins with valves that join the superficial to the deep venous system.

Highyeild:

The small saphenous vein (SSV) originates from the lateral side of the dorsal venous arch and accompanies the sural nerve as it passes posterior to the lateral malleolus, then upwards in the posterior midline of the leg. In the proximal calf, it is usually found sitting in the groove between the two muscular heads of the gastrocnemius. Its termination commonly occurs by piercing the fascia of the popliteal fossa to drain into the popliteal vein at the saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ). However, this junction is highly variable and the vein may terminate as low as the mid-calf. The SSV may extend cranially beyond the SPJ, in which case it is known as either a cranial extension of the SSV, which terminates by piercing the fascia in the posterior thigh to drain into the deep system or the Giacomini vein, which communicates with the GSV system occasionally joining the GSV at or about the SFJ. In some cases, the SSV does not terminate at or below the popliteal fossa at all but continues on as described above.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. The saphenofemoral junction is situated 2.5–3 cm below and lateral to the pubic tubercle. This anatomical landmark is important when making an incision to perform groin dissection for varicose vein surgery. Option: B. The LSV starts at the medial part of the dorsal venous arch of the foot and is accompanied by the saphenous nerve in front of and above the medial malleolus. This anatomical fact is important when performing a venous cut-down for open intravenous access and not to strip a varicose vein down to the ankle. Option: C. The SSV originates on the lateral aspect of the dorsal venous arch and lies behind the lateral malleolus with the sural nerve. It ascends along the lateral edge of the Achilles tendon in the subcutaneous fat covered by skin and superficial fascia. In its ascent, it passes between the two heads of the gastrocnemius to terminate in the popliteal vein above the knee joint.

Up to 40% of the adult population in resource-rich countries have diseases of the veins of the leg. As the sole of the foot is often placed under significant pressure, the majority of the venous drainage of the foot is into the dorsal venous arch, running in the subcutaneous tissues over the metatarsal heads.

Highyeild:

Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome This is a combined anomaly of a cutaneous naevus, persistent vestigial veins with varicose veins and soft tissue, and bone hypertrophy . The condition is a mesodermal abnormality that is not familial. Segments of the deep veins are hypoplastic or aplastic and there may be an associated obstruction of the lymphatics. The condition must be distinguished from the Parkes-Weber syndrome, in which there are multiple arteriovenous fistulae causing venous hypertension, ulceration, and high-output cardiac failure. Virtually all patients with Klippel–Trenaunay syndrome should be treated conservatively with compression hosiery; however, some will benefit from laser ablation of the naevus, stapling of the bones to avoid leg length discrepancy, and occasional removal of large superficial varicose veins, provided the deep veins are patent. LMWH should be given to all patients having surgery as this syndrome is associated with an increased risk of VTE.
